data.title: Variable expressions in template strings are no longer being highlighted
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 7ba55c5860b152d999dda59393ca3ebeb1b5c85f
- OS Version: OS X El Cap 10.11.5

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create a `.js` file
2. Write a template string.

![VS Code Screenshot](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/829827/20582007/c94ff368-b191-11e6-9ea3-375ecdd0262d.png)

I would expect to see the `${expr}` to be highlighted separately from the rest of the string. VS Code used to do this, but has stopped with more recent releases.

data.title: Turn on ```editor.formatOnType``` for a particular language
data.body:
For the [Python](https://github.com/DonJayamanne/pythonVSCode) extension I have a custom [OnTypeFormattingEditProvider](https://github.com/DonJayamanne/pythonVSCode/blob/master/src/client/typeFormatters/blockFormatProvider.ts) that ensures certain blocks of code are properly indented.

For instance if the user were to type the following code in Python:  
```python
if x == y:
    print(x)
    else:
```
After typing in the text ```print(x)``` at line 2, the user hits enter:  
- The cursor at this point will be indented and positioned under the letter ```p```   
- Then types the string ```else:```

In Python the position of ```else:``` is incorrect. It needs to be at the same indentation level as the corresponding ```if```.  This is where the OnTypeFormattingEditProvider comes in, it will automatically format that line (by removing the unnecessary white space).

It works as expected.

However, Python users will have to manually turn on the setting ```editor.formatOnType``` in their user or workspace settings. 

**I.e. almost everyone using this extension will miss out on this (very useful and crucial) feature.**  

- Is there a way for the extension to turn this on as a default value?  
I know I could manually alter the ```enditor.formatOnType``` value via code. Is that the right approach? Would that not affect other languages as well?  
- Or is there a way to turn this on for a specific language, ```Python``` in this case?

data.title: Fix missing 'set' command that was causing a useless error.
data.body: Was following the instructions for the first time to set up my local environment for contributing to VSCode and I noticed when I ran .\scripts\code.bat as instructed that the script emitted an error about INSTALLEDVERSION being unknown. At first I thought I had mis-configured something but looking at the code.bat file there is an obvious omission of a 'set' command. Simple fix.

In the gif above, the `'` is automatically paired as I am writing the sentence, even though I am writing a comment and `'` used as an apostrophe is more likely to happen.

data.title: Leading space in before-decorators is trimmed.
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Version 1.7.2
- OS Version: Windows 10 RS1

Steps to Reproduce:

Writing a vscode-istanbul plugin that shows coverage data right inside vscode.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1018196/20574163/1240a8b2-b168-11e6-96ed-617cf9652d30.png)

The leading space for statement hits is not shown.

Decorator is created as following:

```
    const decoration = {
        range: new vscode.Range(pos.line - 1, pos.column, pos.line - 1, pos.column),
        hoverMessage: null,
        renderOptions: {
            before: {
                contentText:` ${hitCount} `,
                backgroundColor: hitCount ? hitBgColor : notHitBgColor,
                color: "rgba(255,255,255,0.5)",
            }
        }
    }

```

contentText has leading and trailing space.

data.title: dupe module
data.body: After running `npm install` for the extensions-folder check for identical (name & version) modules in the *parent folder* and remove dupes.

4. and I get :

data.title: Suggestion on installing pylint comes with malformed terminal command
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.7.2 (1.7.2)
- OS Version: macOS 10.11.6 El Capitan

Steps to Reproduce:

1. From a fresh VSCode installation, open python file (*.py)
2. Click "Install pylint" in the appearing banner:

![screen shot 2016-11-23 at 18 38 30](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/994357/20572663/a7afac9c-b1ac-11e6-9e7e-816ba1ab1dad.png)

3. See failing command in terminal `python -m -m pip install pylint`:

![screen shot 2016-11-23 at 18 38 37](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/994357/20572666/abfe95f6-b1ac-11e6-82b8-5b80779eaf79.png)

### Solution

Enter the proper command:

```bash
python -m pip install pylint
```

data.title: UI for adding snippets in launch.json
A failed build should either prompt to or bring up the problems window
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.7.2
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:

1.  Load up functional typescript project (like Hello World), that has a tsc on watch mode.
2. Type in a line that will cause an error, for example, import pug = require("pug"); without npm installing or typings installing
3. Hit F5 to run.
4. Top bay shows up with message "A build error has been detected during preLaunch task "tsc"

It should instead ask "Would you like to see your problems?" - or just automatically bring up problems window, which correctly displays the compile error. In this case, "Cannot find module "pug".

data.title: markers hidden by decorations
data.body:
- Monaco Editor Version: 0.7.0
- OS Version: Chrome

Hi,

We create an editor for a custom language.
The editor holds queries, separated by empty lines.
We use changeDecorations in order to highlight the current query according to the user cursor position.
The decoration use a class that sets the background-color.
I'm working on adding a validation check that will mark errors in the query. I'm using setModelMarkers for that.

It seems that the error marker is 'hidden' by the decoration. 

How do I use both markers and decorations for the same position?

Thanks,
Anat

data.title: Too easy to mistakenly move files
data.body:
Does anyone else find it's way too easy to mistakenly drag and drop files into new folders?

Please excuse if you don't. But I've found it's very easy to move files by mistake when working on big projects and can be a nightmare trying to find where you dropped the file if, especially in a large file tree structure.

Again, this might be me and my clumsy hands so apologies, but I think it would be awesome to at least turn on an option to confirm file drag and drops. That way people who don't care for the feature wouldn't have it foisted on them.

data.body:

- Extensions:

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|material-icon-theme|PKief|1.1.3|
|code-settings-sync|Shan|2.3.8|
|sort-lines|Tyriar|1.1.0|
|html-css-class-completion|Zignd|1.0.3|
|Bookmarks|alefragnani|0.10.0|
|project-manager|alefragnani|0.12.2|
|one-monokai|azemoh|0.1.15|
|vscode-eslint|dbaeumer|1.1.0|
|githistory|donjayamanne|0.1.0|
|tslint|eg2|0.6.3|
|Angular2|johnpapa|1.0.2|
|theme-karyfoundation-themes|karyfoundation|8.0.2|
|HTMLHint|mkaufman|0.0.3|
|vscode-stylefmt|mrmlnc|2.1.0|
|Theme-1337|ms-vscode|0.1.2|
|angular2-inline|natewallace|0.0.16|
|nonbreakingspace|smlombardi|0.0.1|
|vscode-icons|robertohuertasm|4.0.2|
|stylelint|shinnn|0.20.1|
|theme-tesla|smlombardi|5.0.0|
|bootstrap-3-snippets|wcwhitehead|0.0.8|
|change-case|wmaurer|1.0.0|

---

Steps to Reproduce:

I have been working with this file for weeks in VSCode Insiders.  Today, with the most recent update, certain things are being flagged as errors -- which are not errors.

I get this even when running with `--disable-extensions`

1. open a file with some "non-standard" html attributes like `ng-options` or `data-content`.  I am using [this file](http://jmp.sh/ZYxajzU).
2. the `data-content` strings have an error for every wors, for missing a semicolon:

![screen shot 2016-11-23 at 10 09 53 am](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/835148/20567268/1c1b632e-b166-11e6-89b6-2440b2c7129f.jpg)

![screen shot 2016-11-23 at 10 18 30 am](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/835148/20567304/31e48c9e-b166-11e6-9563-3fc0610024da.jpg)

and the `ng-options` string complains about missing parens:

![screen shot 2016-11-23 at 10 19 07 am](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/835148/20567336/4a087240-b166-11e6-8bdc-4cc7ebe2f992.jpg)

![screen shot 2016-11-23 at 10 19 25 am](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/835148/20567346/52c6d458-b166-11e6-9e4f-7de793362d76.jpg)

Neither of these cases are errors at all, and these were never flagged before.

data.title: Hardcoded number of viewlets in CSS
data.body:
https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/master/src/vs/workbench/parts/explorers/media/treeExplorer.contribution.css#L16

For one, this contribution shouldn't reach out to the activity bar like that at all. Second, why is that `nth-child(n+6)` in there? It hardcodes the number of non-contributed viewlets we currently have.

data.title: Recommend changing ignoreTrimWhitespace default to false

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
I recommend modifying VS code to default to diffEditor.ignoreTrimWhitespace = false to maintain parity with git diff.  On my team whitespace is a big part of the code review and beautification process.  Not being able to see the whitespace in a diff lead me down a rabbit hole.  That's not a good place to be for a new user.

More details on my initial experiences with this:  http://stackoverflow.com/questions/30140595/show-whitespace-characters-in-visual-studio-code/40744352#40744352

data.title: find/replace not triggering didChange
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.7.2
- OS Version: OS X 10.11.6

Steps to Reproduce:

1. open 3 files with the same string in it.
2. Search + replace for that string.
3. Language server protocol only fires a change event for one of the changed files.

  Same thing happens for a rename request.
  https://github.com/Microsoft/language-server-protocol/blob/master/protocol.md#rename-request 


What I expected:

a `textDocument/didChange` for every file that was changed.

data.title: [css] show styles found in html

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
Is it possible to have classes that are declared only in the markup to be shown trough intellisense in our styles?

Is it possible for the class caching to **_listen_** for added/removed classes from both the styles and markup instead of this happening @ startup or doing it manually?

![image of class caching](http://i.imgur.com/O7NjEUW.gif)

Right now the exact opposite is possible through the [**HTML CSS Class Completion plugin**](https://github.com/Zignd/HTML-CSS-Class-Completion) , but it will be great if one can do the opposite as well. Meaning - when I type a dot in a stylesheet, intellisense should pop-up a list with all the available classes in my html, which do not exist in my current styles.

I know this is more like an IDE feature, but I would love to hear Your opinions about it.

Thanks in advance!

data.title: Test: read environment variables from external file
data.body:
Test for #14523:

- [x] Windows - **@ramya-rao-a**
- [x] OS X - **@bpasero** 
- [x] Linux - **@rebornix** 

Complexity: 2

The VS Code Node debugger now supports to load environment variables from a file and passes them to the node runtime.
To use this feature add an attribute `envFile` to your launch config and specify the absolute path to the file containing the environment variables:
```ts
   //...
   "envFile": "${workspaceRoot}/.env",
   "env": { "USER": "john doe" }
   //...
```
Any environment variable specified in `env` dictionary will override variables loaded from the file that have a matching name.

Example for env file:
```
USER=doe
PASSWORD=abc123

# a comment

# an empty value:
empty=

# new lines expanded in quoted strings:
lines="foo\nbar"

```

Verify that this feature works as specified.

data.title: TypeScript server not working on Ubuntu 16.04
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.7.2 (7ba55c5860b152d999dda59393ca3ebeb1b5c85f, 2016-11-21T22:14:18.217Z)
- OS Version: Linux x64 4.4.0-47-generic
- Extensions:

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|xml|DotJoshJohnson|1.6.0|
|java|redhat|0.0.6|

---

Hi Microsoft!

I'm very happy with vscode in general - good work!
However, I'm unable to get embedded TypeScript server to work on Ubuntu 16.04 with Node.js. vscode was installed using the .deb file.

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Install node.js version 6.9.1 LTS
2. npm init
3: npm install express --save
4: Create .js file and import any core module (for instance 'express' or 'fs'.

Recieving the following error in output:

[Info  - 3:14:09 PM] Using tsserver from location: /usr/share/code/resources/app/extensions/typescript/node_modules/typescript/lib/tsserver.js
[Error - 3:14:22 PM] 'completions' request failed with error.
Error processing request. Cannot read property 'length' of undefined
TypeError: Cannot read property 'length' of undefined
    at getCompletionEntriesFromTypings (/usr/share/code/resources/app/extensions/typescript/node_modules/typescript/lib/tsserver.js:48215:79)
    at getCompletionEntriesForNonRelativeModules (/usr/share/code/resources/app/extensions/typescript/node_modules/typescript/lib/tsserver.js:48094:17)
    at getStringLiteralCompletionEntriesFromModuleNames (/usr/share/code/resources/app/extensions/typescript/node_modules/typescript/lib/tsserver.js:47985:31)
    at getStringLiteralCompletionEntries (/usr/share/code/resources/app/extensions/typescript/node_modules/typescript/lib/tsserver.js:47889:28)
    at Object.getCompletionsAtPosition (/usr/share/code/resources/app/extensions/typescript/node_modules/typescript/lib/tsserver.js:47773:24)
    at IOSession.Session.getCompletions (/usr/share/code/resources/app/extensions/typescript/node_modules/typescript/lib/tsserver.js:54974:64)
    at Session.handlers.ts.createMap._a.(anonymous function) (/usr/share/code/resources/app/extensions/typescript/node_modules/typescript/lib/tsserver.js:54219:61)
    at IOSession.Session.executeCommand (/usr/share/code/resources/app/extensions/typescript/node_modules/typescript/lib/tsserver.js:55286:28)
    at IOSession.Session.onMessage (/usr/share/code/resources/app/extensions/typescript/node_modules/typescript/lib/tsserver.js:55306:35)
    at Interface.<anonymous> (/usr/share/code/resources/app/extensions/typescript/node_modules/typescript/lib/tsserver.js:56389:27)
